question: What has the government done to encourage industrialization in Nigeria?
answer:
Government has done the following to encourage Industrialization:

(i) A reasonable level of infrastructure is evident in Nigeria :- There are better systems of road networks, especially the express roads, efficient telecommunications, electricity and water supply systems.

(ii) The Federal Government gives tax concession to pioneer industries for a specified number of years during which the company will not pay tax.

(iii) The governments protect infant industries through high import duties, outright bans or quotas on imported Commodities which compete with those of home industries.

(iv) The government has also established industrial estates, and thus reduced the problem of locating industries in urban towns.

(v) The Nigeria Enterprises Promotion Decree of 1972 was an attempt by the Federal Military Government to transfer part of the profits generated in Nigeria to the local people.

(vi) The government has established financial institutions to aid private enterprises e.g. Nigeria Bank for Commerce and Industry and Nigerian industrial Bank.

(vii) The development of human resources through the establishment of universities and Colleges of Technology.

(viii) Relaxing of industrial laws such as the Indigenization policy.

(ix) Nigeria has undertaken development plans aimed at controlling the resources allocation.

(x) Increase of industrial loans that have enabled more businessmen to obtain loans and establish more industries.

question:
(a) What is demand- pull inflation?
(b) Why is price control not suitable in checking this type of inflation?
answer:
(a)Demand - pull theory of inflation states that changes in price level are brought about by a disequilibrium in markets caused by changes in aggregate demand. Buyers bids eagerly for goods and services, Pulling up their prices.

(b) (i) Goods are in short supply.
(ii) Buyers will prefer buying at higher price rather than going home without any goods.
(iii) The interaction of the forces of demand and supply will work against price control system.
(iv) Price control system is prone to a lot of malpractices.
(v) The existence of black market will contribute a lot in making price control not suitable in checking demand - pull inflation.

question:
(a) Briefly outline the views of Thomas Malthus about population.
(b) How valid are such views about the Nigerian situation today?
answer:
(a) Features of Malthusian theory are:

(i) That population was growing at a geometrical progression while food production was growing at a Arithmetical progression.

(ii) That there is a tendency for all living things to grow beyond the food available to them.

(iii) Unless population increase is matched with means of subsistence, negative and positive checks will come into force.

(iv) That the checks can be disease, epidemics, famine

(b) Malthus' views are valid with Nigerian situation today for the following reasons:

(i) The population of Nigeria is increasing as a result of negative attitude.

(ii) Human population in Nigeria is presently growing at a geometrical progression while food production is growing at arithmetical progression.

(iii) Poverty which is inherent in a given society according to Maithus, has proved extremely difficult to be wiped out in Nigeria.

(iv) Rapid population growth militates against rapid economic development and it grows faster than Per Capital Income.

(v) The standard of living has fallen as a result of increase in population.

question: Explain the uses of national income figures.
answer:
Uses of national income figures include:

(i) Economic planning: National income statistics assist the government in planning economic development. Successful planning requires fairly accurate figures upon which decisions can be based.

(ii) For estimating per capita income: Average per capita income can easily be obtained if the national income is known.

(iii) Measurement of standard of living: National Income statistics are used to indicate the overall standard of living of the people. The larger the size of income, the higher the standard of living of people, provided that the income is equitably distributed.

(iv) Useful guide to investors: The data gathered on people's expenditure incomes and outputs will put investors in position to know whether it is worth investing their capital in the Country or not.

(v) Comparison of economic growth among countries: National income statistics are used to compare the living standards of different countries. This is done on the basis of average income per head.

(vi) National Income statistics also give vital information about the different sectors of the economy, their rate of growth, their needs for resource allocation.

(vii) National income figures can show at a glance whether or not the country's economy is growing from year to year and at what rate.

(viii) National income statistics will indicate areas of greatest needs in terms of resources allocation and appropriate measures will be taken to correct the imbalance.

question:
Write short notes on
(a) Liquidity Ratio.
(b) Fixed Deposits.
(c) Money Market.
answer:
(a) Liquidity ratio: The commercial banks are required by the law to keep a specified proportion of their total deposits with the Central Bank in the form of bank reserves, usually 25% of their total deposits. The size of the reserve can be raised or lowered according to the economic exigences of the country. If the Central Bank needs to adopt a credit squeeze stance, it would raise the reservation. If the Central needs to adopt an expansionist policy, it would lower the legal reserve ratios of the commercial banks.

(b) Fixed deposits: This is operated by people who can afford to keep their money in the bank for reasonable long period without making any withdrawal from the account. The period can extend up to a year or more. Individuals , firms and government use fixed deposit account for keeping money they do not need at present. The customer receives a higher interest rate than on the ordinary savings account. Before the money in fixed deposit account is withdrawn, the bank must be given between 7 to 14 days notice.

(c) Money market: This is a market for short terms loans. The loan granted can be demanded at short notice. The money market is made up of the following institutions : Commercial banks, Central Bank, Discount houses and Bill brokers.

question: The bulk of West African foreign trade is directed away from Africa to Europe and America. What are the reasons for this?
answer:
(i) Industries that make use of the raw materials which are the main products of West African countries are found in Europe and America.

(ii) The world economic order tends to be in favour of the developed countries.

(iii) Absence of developed markets in Africa where our system of exchange is still underdeveloped and there is low demand as a result of low per Capital Income.

(iv) Over reliance on foreign products has made West Africans to have the notion that foreign products are superior.

(v) Ineffective transport and communication systems in Africa.

(vi) African countries produce mainly agricultural products and that makes exchange of goods between them very difficult.

(vii) Low level of technological development makes it difficult for African countries to produce goods needed in the continent, hence, our going to Europe and America.

(viii) Also, capital goods which West Africans depend heavenly upon are mainly produced in Europe and America.

question: Discuss the important role played by agriculture in the economy of your country.
answer:
Importance of Agriculture in the economy of my country are:

(i)It provides food for the populace, thus ensuring that people are well fed.

(ii) It provides raw materials needed by the industrial sector e.g Cocoa for Bournvita and maize for cornflour.

(iii) Agriculture provides revenue for farmers and the agricultural sector generates a sizeable part of the National Income.

(iv) Agriculture offers employment to many Nigerians who would have been jobless.

(v) Agriculture provides a market for industrial products such as hoes, machetes, fertilizer and insecticides.

(vi) It fetches foreign exchange for the country following the export of its raw materials.

(vii) It serves as a source of tax revenue in that the export duty imposed on exported raw materials is a source of revenue to thd government.

question:
(a) What are the objectives of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) ?
(b) What are the problems of the OPEC?
(c) What remedies have been adopted to curtail them?
answer:
(a)Objectives of OPEC are:
(i) To maintain stability of oil price.
(ii) To ensure steady supply of oil to consuming nations.
(iii) To encourage the exploration, exploitation and development of the petroleum resources of member countries
(iv) Stabilization of oil income of its member- nations.
(v) To co-ordinate the petroleum policies of its member- countries and to improve their bargaining power.
(vi) It fixes and allocates production quota to member nations.
(vii) To increase its control over the oil industry.

(b) Problems of OPEC are:
(i) The rivalry for the leadership of the organization between Saudi-Arabia and Iran is a big problem to OPEC.

(ii) The emergence in the international oil market in the 1980's of the North sea oil producers of the UK and Norway.

(iii) The constant disagreement between members of OPEC in the fixing of prices and production quotas, and failure to implement agreed prices and production quotas.

(iv) The activities of the advanced nations in stock piling oil which contributes to the fall of oil prices is causing problem for OPEC.

(v) The world economic depression has brought about fall in oil prices.

(vi) There is increasing research by the advanced countries to find substitute for oil.

(vii) Political disagreements which sometimes lead to war between member-nations like Iran and Iraq war caused a serious problem to OPEC.

(c) Remedies adopted to curtail the problems of OPEC are:
(i) Penalties have been imposed on its members.
(ii) The members of OPEC have embarked on joint research to counteract that of the western and advanced nations to find substitute for oil.
(iii) The organisations is making effort to create unity among its members.
(iv) The key posts in the organisation are being rotated among the member -nations.
(v) OPEC tries to maintain a reasonable price in order to avoid price fluctuation.
